Award.AbstractNarration:
Animals can move through the world in remarkably complex and effective ways that are still difficult or impossible to replicate in machines. This is particularly evident in soft animals such as octopus, worms and caterpillars which can change shape as they move. A long-term goal of this research is to understand how boneless animals control their bodies and to apply this knowledge in the design and fabrication of entirely new types of robot. In effect, soft animals are working prototypes for all sorts of new devices. Using a well-established model animal (the caterpillar, Manduca sexta) these experiments will simultaneously collect data on the mechanical performance and neural signals driving behavior. New measuring devices (e.g., flexible electrode arrays, micro-force beams) and computational methods have been developed to carry out these studies. Working with engineers, these data will be used to build mathematical models that control and simulate soft animal movements. One outcome will be the first explanation of how a massively deformable structure can be controlled using a few simple commands.

In addition to developing a better understanding of animal movements, these studies will have an impact in the fields of engineering and robotics. One immediate effect will be new cross-disciplinary training opportunities for biology and engineering students. A broader impact will be through the public availability of these results for scientists and engineers to develop their own soft material research tools and applications for future technologies.

One potential outcome is the production of Soft Robots for diagnostic and therapeutic use inside the body or for other applications that need extreme mobility (e.g., search and rescue robots for disaster situations). These new machines could be cheap, safe, and biodegradable alternatives to current devices.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit. Neuromechanics is the study of how the brain and body interact to control animal behavior. This interaction is of particular importance for soft animals because the body can deform in ways that are impossible for those with rigid skeletons.  This research has used caterpillars as a model system to identify the mechanisms of crawling and climbing in complex structures. Experiments on caterpillars allow a unique combination of techniques to be applied simultaneously. This combination includes recording neural activity, measuring the forces exerted on the environment and tracking movements during natural behavior. Important new findings are that; 1) the brain can exploit the mechanical properties of soft tissues to maintain stability and control, 2) soft animals can use a tensile strategy (the Environmental Skeleton) to avoid stiffening the body when they crawl, 3) shifts in global neural motor activity occur in response to changes in the environment (such as orientation to gravity) even when the movements themselves are unchanged.  

Broader Impacts. In addition to the biological and potential agricultural importance of these findings, understanding how caterpillars sense and respond to different environments has wide application in robotics, including the design and control of soft multifunctional climbing machines, and for building assistive devices and manipulators. This work has led to the development of new types of 3D-printed soft research robots (Softworms) that are expected to have applications in environmental monitoring, search and rescue, and low gravity tasks in space. As a key part of the research new flexible multielectrode arrays were designed and fabricated for recording the electrical activity of fine muscles and they are currently being developed for rehabilitation of facial muscle pathologies and as a diagnostic product. This research requires expertise in biology, engineering and materials sciences. It has therefore been the basis of an interdisciplinary research training program for undergraduates, graduates and postdoctoral fellows from diverse backgrounds.
